title: Why didn't Mark Anthony try to become the emperor of Rome after Caesar's death as he was more powerful than Augustus? - Quora

response.answer_text: He didn’t “try to become emperor” for a few reasons: There was not yet any such position as “emperor.” Nobody had held that kind of power in Rome since the ancient kings.Even Augustus was not called emperor. He knew that Rome would rebel against any such open desire for absolute power. He called himself “First Citizen” and deliberately dressed simply, kept a traditional house, etc., instead of cloaking himself in grandeur. This caution served him well. The position of a “supreme leader” was not one anybody openly aspired to for a very long time after Julius Caesar’s assassination.Mark Antony did make aggressive plays for power, first in the Triumvirates and then through his alliance with Cleopatra. It is incorrect to assume that he simply didn’t go after the ultimate prize. It’s more that he (and other power players at that point) weren’t yet sure what that ultimate prize would actually be.Mark Antony began stronger than Augustus, but Augustus managed to change that. Although not a brilliant military leader himself, Augustus had the strong loyalty of the great general Agrippa, with whom he’d been friends since boyhood. Caesar’s troops were even more loyal to Caesar’s heir, Augustus, than they were to Caesar’s friend, Antony. Furthermore, Augustus knew to pay the armies often and well. Although Octavian/Augustus was only 19 when he was thrown into this real-life “Game of Thrones,” he had uncanny instincts for politics and learned quickly how to gain allies and consolidate power.Antony simply wasn’t as smart as Augustus. By allying with Cleopatra, Marc Antony opened himself up to charges that he had abandoned Rome and Roman virtues, that he had become corrupted. His temper led him sometimes to make rash decisions that weakened his alliances and power while strengthening Augustus’. Although Marc Antony was no fool and could be very shrewd, he lacked Augustus’ extraordinary foresight and patience.
